results.title: Les Cousins de 'la Constance': Episode 2
results.creator_credit: Robert Mazoyer and Marcel Degliame Fouche
results.brief_description:
In order to gather finances to buy ‘La Constance’, the Guillous have to sell shares in their fishing business to local villagers. They are still working hard at convincing Mother Guillou to sell her treasured land to make up for the short fall. Meanwhile, Yves and Marie-Josee are moving their abode to the basement. The Summer season has arrived and the whole house is rented out to the family of a Parisian doctor.

Credits: Producer, Marcel Degliame Fouche ; director, Robert Mazoyer ; writer, Paul Guimard ; photography, Jean-Jacques Guyard ; music, Georges Delerue.
Cast: Jean Le Mouel, Claude Brosset, Lucien Barjon, Andree Tainsy, Jean-Marc Epinoux, Dominique Mac Avoy, Elina Labourdette, Jean-Pierre Kerien, Catherine Seynes.

results.title: Les Cousins de 'la Constance': Episode 1
results.creator_credit: Robert Mazoyer and Marcel Degliame Fouche
results.brief_description:
Jean, the eldest son of the Guillous is returning to his village in Brittany after 8 months spent on a fishing boat, off the coast of Senegal. He has big plans to buy his own boat and employ his father, a retired fisherman, and his cousin Yves, a mechanic. Yves, a married man with two children, is keen on becoming a share-holder in a fishing enterprise. So is old man Guillou. The men have their heart set on buying ‘La Constance’. But, the financing of the project depends partially on Mother Guillou and the sale of a piece of land that was given to her as a dowry. For the women of the Guillou clan, the mother, Marie-Josee, Yves’ wife and Anne, Marie-Josee’s sister, the great adventure of ‘La Constance’ means more worrying and waiting by the radio, listening for weather and ship movements reports. It also means balancing tight budgets by opening the house to summer invaders: Parisian tourists. Les cousins de ‘La Constance’ is a faithful portraiture of the ‘real’ Brittany, its landscapes, its inhabitants, its ‘patois’ as well as a good introduction to the rites and rituals of the world of fishermen.

Credits: Producer, Marcel Degliame Fouche ; director, Robert Mazoyer ; writer, Paul Guimard ; photography, Jean-Jacques Guyard ; music, Georges Delerue.
Cast: Jean Le Mouel, Claude Brosset, Lucien Barjon, Andree Tainsy, Jean-Marc Epinoux, Dominique Mac Avoy, Elina Labourdette, Jean-Pierre Kerien, Catherine Seynes.

results.title: Lumiere D'ete = Summer Light
results.brief_description:
An ex-dancer runs an isolated mountain hotel where the guests are ‘people with problems’. This melancholy allegory about characters living on the edge of a figurative and literal abyss, was made under the restrictions of Vichy France and at times threatened by censorship. Visually, [during the Occupation] the new films became more mannered and stylized, surpassing even the expressionistic vistas of ‘realisme poetique’ in their creation of visual fields removed both from every day reality and from the characters who moved within them. Some works returned to overt pictorialism of late silent film, perhaps most notably Gremillon and Prevert’s ‘Lumiere d’Ete’. Sets were often large and elaborate, despite obvious financial difficulties that this entailed in a period of limited resources. Roger Regent, one of the period’s most astute observers, spoke of the ‘decor-personnage’ (the set as character) as being an often abused cinematic cliche. If decor could frequently function as a kind of (impersonal) character, fictional beings could by the same token lapse into relative, sometimes absolute stillness, assuming the function of decor in a larger, metaphysical drama.” Reference: Alan Williams. “Republic of Image: a history of French filmmaking”. Harvard University Press, 1992

Credits: Producer, Andre Paulve ; director, Jean Gremillon ; writers, Jacques Prevert, Pierre Laroche ; photography, Louis Page ; music, Roland Manuel ; art direction, Max Douy, Louis Barsacq.
Cast: Paul Bernard, Madeleine Renaud, Pierre Brasseur, Madeleine Robinson, Raymond Aimos, Georges Marchal, Jane Marken, Charles Blavette.

results.title: La Prise du Pouvoir Par Louis XIV = The Rise of Louis XIV
results.brief_description:
At the death of Cardinal Mazarin in 1661, Louis XIV, seconded by Colbert, imposes to France his concept of absolute monarchy. It is as if a documentary cameraman had been let loose in the royal court of the 17th century Sun King. The use of unfamiliar actors in the major roles adds to the film’s realism. Though shown to be the product of a decadent lifestyle, Louis is depicted as being trapped by his royalty, forced in spite of himself to be a raconteur and trendsetter. ‘The Rise of Louis XIV’ was one of several innovative films directed for French television by Roberto Rossellini.

Credits: Director, Roberto Rossellini ; writers, Philippe Erlanger, Jean Gruault ; photography, Georges Leclerc.
Cast: Jean-Marie Patte, Raymond Jourdan, Silvagni, Katharina Renn.

results.title: Soleil Dans L'oeil = Sun in the Eyes (Cinemascope Print)
results.creator_credit: Jacques Bourdon, Andre Deroual and Eric Schlumberger
results.brief_description:
Emma moves to Corsica to work on a translation. Every day she writes to Denis, her lover, who still lives in Paris. She becomes acquainted with Frederic, a local musician and finds herself torn between two lovers.

Credits: Producers, Eric Schlumberger, Andre Deroual ; director, Jacques Bourdon ; writers, Dominique Aury, Eric Schlumberger, Jacques Bourdon ; photography, Lucien Joulin ; music, Maurice Jarre
Cast: Anna Karina, Georges Descrieres, Jacques Perrin, Charles Blavette, Nadine Alari.

results.title: La Bete Humaine = the Human Beast
results.creator_credit: Jean Renoir, Raymond Hakim and Robert Hakim
results.brief_description:
“So that the trains and the costumes of another era would not distract his audience, Jean Renoir situated his adaptation of Zola’s novel in 1938. He wanted to make a true tragedy. The hero, Jacques Lantier, is haunted by the curse of alcoholism, and the action from start to finish has a driving intensity that Zola would not have disavowed. Lantier burns with passion for Severine, a strange little creature whose callowness results in a kind of nonchalance bordering on frigidity. She is the accomplice of her jealous husband and passively assists in the murder of her old benefactor and lover. Lantier catches them in the act, and out of love says nothing. He is unable to kill her husband when she asks him to and he ends up strangling her in a fit of passion. Mad with grief, he kills himself, which is not the way Zola ended his novel. Right before his suicide comes one of the most beautiful moments in film, the justly famous Trainmen’s ball”. Reference: Celia Bertin. ‘Jean Renoir: a life in pictures’. London: John Hopkins University Press, 1991. Jean Renoir appears briefly as Cabuche, the poacher. In this film, Renoir perhaps came closest to the dark mood of fatalistic ‘poetic realism’ that characterised the works of Carne and Duvivier in the 1930s. In August 1939, on the eve of WWII, the French Ministry of Information drew up a list of 51 ‘depressing, morbid, immoral and bad for the youths’ films, including ‘La Bete Humaine’. Re-made in the USA by Fritz Lang as ‘Human Desire’ (1954) with Glenn Ford, Gloria Grahame, Edgar Buchanan.

Credits: Producer, Robert and Raymond Hakim ; director, writer, Jean Renoir ; photography, Curt Courant, Claude Renoir ; music, Joseph Kosma ; art direction, Eugene Lourie ; editor, Marguerite Renoir ; stills photographer, Sam Levin.
Cast: Credits: Jean Gabin, Simone Simon, Fernand Ledoux, Blanchette Brunoy, Julien Carette.

results.title: Les Parents Terribles
results.creator_credit: Jean Cocteau, Alexandre Mnouchkine and Francis Cosne
results.brief_description:
When the son of a middle-class Parisian family announces his love for a young woman, neither he nor his domineering mother, who cannot accept his adulthood, know that the girl is the mistress of his father. Reference: Bloomsbury Film Guide.

Credits: Producers, Alexandre Mnouchkine, Francis Cosne ; writer, director, Jean Cocteau ; photography, Michel Kelber ; music, Georges Auric.
Cast: Jean Marais, Josette Day, Yvonne de Bray, Marcel Andre, Gabrielle Dorziat.

results.title: Montparnasse 19 = Modigliani of Montparnasse
results.brief_description:
Set in the bohemian quarter of Montparnasse (Paris) at the turn of the century, ‘Montparnasse 19’ follows the last days of the life of Modigliani. Thinking he is a failed painter, Modigliani has become an alcoholic. He survives thanks to the generosity of Rosalie, a restaurant owner, and his friend Zborovski. An art merchant, Morel, recognises the talent of the young painter, but prefers to wait patiently for his death in order to cash in.

Credits: Producer, Ralph Baum ; director, Jacques Becker ; writer, Henri Jeanson ; photography, Christian Matras ; music, Paul Misraki ; editor, Marguerite Renoir ; art direction, Jean d’Eaubonne.
Cast: Gerard Philipe, Anouk Aimee, Gerard Sety, Lino Ventura, Lili Palmer, Lea Padovani, Lila Kedrova, Marianne Oswald, Jean Lanier.

results.title: A Bout de Souffle = Breathless (Reserve Print)
results.creator_credit: Jean-Luc Godard and Georges de Beauregard
results.brief_description:
Michel, on the run after shooting a policeman, is betrayed by his girlfriend, Patricia, an expatriate American. The plot is drawn from the ‘B’ crime thriller (the film is dedicated to Monogram Pictures, Hollywood’s all-B movie studio) and Godard pays homage to Hollywood’s action genres but his free approach to narrative and stylistics made this the most original and influential of the early New Wave films. The theme of the limits of personal freedom on the boundary between anarchism and nihilism emerges almost casually. The sense of dislocation is most obvious in Godard’s use of the jump cut, a device which he rarely, if ever, used again although he retained the effect. A more accurate translation of the title is ‘out of breath’ rather than the more romantic ‘breathless’.

Credits: Producer, Georges de Beauregard ; director, writer, Jean-Luc Godard ; photography, Raoul Coutard ; music, Martial Solal.
Cast: Jean-Paul Belmondo, Jean Seberg, Jean-Pierre Melville, Roger Hanin, Daniel Boulanger, Richard Balducci.

results.title: Le Chant du Depart
results.brief_description:
Every Wednesday the members of the ‘lonely heart’ club gather in a private house. They have decided to commit a collective suicide, but at the last minute a voice shouts “No” and the story starts on a new basis: a society where men and women are living in perfect happiness …

Credits: Director, Pascal Aubier ; writer, Pascal Aubier ; photography, Jean-Jacques Flori ; music, Daniel Duval, Horacio Vaggione, Elisabeth Wiener.
Cast: Brigitte Fossey, Rufus, Germaine Montero, Michel de Re, Paulette Frantz, Jacques Rispal.
results.description:
Every Wednesday the members of the ‘lonely heart’ club gather in a private house. They have decided to commit a collective suicide, but at the last minute a voice shouts “No” and the story starts on a new basis: a society where men and women are living in perfect happiness …

Credits: Director, Pascal Aubier ; writer, Pascal Aubier ; photography, Jean-Jacques Flori ; music, Daniel Duval, Horacio Vaggione, Elisabeth Wiener.
Cast: Brigitte Fossey, Rufus, Germaine Montero, Michel de Re, Paulette Frantz, Jacques Rispal.
